S2.T1.caption: Table 1: Rate and complexity comparisons for decentralized FL algorithms.
S2.T1.footnotes: (1) Notation: total iterations Tğ‘‡T, communication set ğ’ssubscriptğ’ğ‘ \mathcal{C}_{s} (|ğ’s|<Tsubscriptğ’ğ‘ ğ‘‡|\mathcal{C}_{s}|<T), client iğ‘–iâ€™s neighborhood ğ’©isubscriptğ’©ğ‘–\mathcal{N}_{i}, maximal bounded delay Ï„ğœ\tau, and client iğ‘–iâ€™s communication time per round ğ’isubscriptğ’ğ‘–\mathscr{C}_{i}. (2) As compared to AD-PSGD, Swift does not have a Ï„ğœ\tau convergence rate term due to using an expected client delay in analysis.
references:
Communication Efficiency. â€ƒMinimizing each client iğ‘–iâ€™s communication time per round ğ’isubscriptğ’ğ‘–\mathscr{C}_{i} is a challenge in FL, as the radius of information exchange can be large (Kairouz etÂ al., 2021).
Matcha (Wang etÂ al., 2019) decomposes the base network into mğ‘šm disjoint matchings.
Every epoch, a random sub-graph is generated from a combination of matchings, each having an activation probability pksubscriptğ‘ğ‘˜p_{k}.
Clients then exchange parameters along this sub-graph.
This requires a total communication-time complexity of ğ’ªâ€‹(Tâ€‹âˆ‘k=1mpkâ€‹maxjâˆˆğ’©iâ¡ğ’j)ğ’ªğ‘‡superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘—subscriptğ’©ğ‘–subscriptğ’ğ‘—\mathcal{O}(T\sum_{k=1}^{m}p_{k}\max_{j\in\mathcal{N}_{i}}\mathscr{C}_{j}), where ğ’©isubscriptğ’©ğ‘–\mathcal{N}_{i} are client iğ‘–iâ€™s neighbors.
LD-SGD (Li etÂ al., 2019) and PA-SGD (Wang & Joshi, 2018) explore how reducing the number of neighborhood parameter exchanges affects convergence.
Both algorithms create a communication set ğ’ssubscriptğ’ğ‘ \mathcal{C}_{s} (defined in Appendix C) that dictate when clients communicate with one another.
The communication-time complexities are listed in Table 1.
These methods, however, are synchronous and their communication-time complexities depend upon the slowest neighbor maxjâˆˆğ’©iâ¡ğ’jsubscriptğ‘—subscriptğ’©ğ‘–subscriptğ’ğ‘—\max_{j\in\mathcal{N}_{i}}\mathscr{C}_{j}.
Swift improves upon this, achieving a communication-time complexity depending on a clientâ€™s own communication-time per round.
Unlike AD-PSGD Lian etÂ al. (2018), which achieves a similar communication-time complexity, Swift allows for periodic communication, uses only local memory, and does not require a bounded-delay assumption.

Major Message from Theoretical Analysis. As summarized in TableÂ 1, the efficiency and effectiveness of decentralized FL algorithms depend on both the iteration convergence rate and communication-time complexity; their product roughly approximates the total time for convergence. In this section, we will prove that Swift improves the SOTA convergence time of decentralized FL as it obtains SOTA iteration convergence rate (TheoremÂ 1) and outperforms SOTA communication-time complexity.

Existing Inter-Client Communication in Decentralized FL.

â€ƒAll clients balance their individual training with inter-client communications in order to achieve consensus while operating in a decentralized manner.
The core idea of decentralized FL is that each client communicates with its neighbors (connected clients) and shares local information.
Balancing individual training with inter-client communication ensures individual client models are well-tailored to personal data while remaining (i) robust to other client data, and (ii) able to converge to an optimal consensus model.
â€ƒAlgorithms such as Periodic Averaging SGD (PA-SGD)
and Local Decentralized SGD (LD-SGD) reduce communication time by performing

local updates before synchronizing.
This process is accomplished through the use of a communication set
, which defines the set of iterations a client must perform synchronization,
We adopt this communication set notation, although synchronization is unneeded in our algorithm.

As expected, when data becomes more non-IID, the test loss becomes higher and the overall accuracy lower (TableÂ 4).
We do see, however, that Swift converges faster, and to a lower average loss, than all other synchronous baselines (FigureÂ 3).
In fact, Swift with ğ’1subscriptğ’1\mathcal{C}_{1} converges much quicker than the synchronous algorithms.
This is an important result: Swift converges both quicker and to a smaller loss than synchronous algorithms in the non-IID setting.

references:
In TableÂ 5, the average epoch, communication, and total time is displayed.
Average total time includes computations, communication, and any added slowdown (wait time).
Swift avoids large average total times as the slowdown grows larger.
The wait-free structure of Swift allows all non-slowed clients to finish their work at their own speed.
All other algorithms require clients to wait for the slowest client to finish a mini-batch before proceeding.
At large slowdowns (4x), the average total time for Swift is nearly half of those for synchronous algorithms.
Thus, Swift is very effective at reducing the run-time when clients are slow within the network.

FigureÂ 4 shows how Swift is able to converge faster to an equivalent, or smaller, test loss than D-SGD for all slowdowns.
In the case of large slowdowns (4x), Swift significantly outperforms D-SGD, finishing in better than half the run-time.
We do not include the other baseline algorithms to avoid overcrowding of the plotting space.
However, Swift also performs much better than PA-SGD and LD-SGD as shown in TableÂ 5.
These results show that the wait-free structure of Swift allows it to be efficient under client slowdown.

Varying Numbers of Clientsâ€ƒIn our fourth experiment, we determine how Swift performs versus other baseline algorithms as we vary the number of clients.
In TableÂ 6, the time per epoch for Swift drops by nearly the optimal factor of 2 as the number of clients is doubled.
For all algorithms, there is a bit of parallel overhead when the number of clients is small, however this becomes minimal as the number of clients grow to be large (greater than 4 clients).
In comparison to the synchronous algorithms, Swift actually decreases its communication time as the number of clients increases.
This allows the parallel performance to be quite efficient, as shown in FigureÂ 5.

In TableÂ 8, one can see that the step-size decay column is split into the following sections: rate, Eğ¸E, and frequency.
The rate is the decay rate for the step-size.
For example, in the Baseline row, the step-size decays by 1/10.
The term Eğ¸E is the epoch at which decay begins during training.
For example, in the Baseline row, the step-size decays at E=81â€‹Â andÂ â€‹122ğ¸81Â andÂ 122E=81\text{ and }122.
Frequency simply is how often the step-size decays.
For example, in the Vary Topology row, the step-size decays every 10 epochs.
